{"comments": {"id": 26780, "count": 75, "talk_id": 2161}, "threadId": 26780, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2161", "description": "Aziz Abu Sarah is a Palestinian activist with an unusual approach to peace-keeping: Be a tourist. The TED Fellow shows how simple interactions with people in different cultures can erode decades of hate. He starts with Palestinians visiting Israelis and moves beyond ...", "event": "TED2014", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Aziz Abu Sarah: For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism?", "slug": "aziz_abu_sarah_for_more_tolerance_we_need_more_tourism", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1823", "slug": "aziz_abu_sarah", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Aziz", "lastname": "Abu Sarah", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Entrepreneur + educator", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/ff02218ac6acc05a6f2764de0225deea00459777_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Aziz Abu Sarah helps people break down cultural and historical barriers through tourism.", "whylisten": "

When Aziz Abu Sarah was a boy, his older brother was arrested on charges of throwing stones. He was taken to prison and beaten — and died of his injuries. Sarah grew up angry, bitter and wanting revenge. But when later in life he met, for the first time, Jews who were not soldiers, Sarah had an epiphany: Not only did they share his love of small things, namely country music, but coming face to face with the “enemy” compelled him to find ways to overcome hatred, anger and fear.

Sarah founded MEJDI Tours to send tourists to Jerusalem with two guides, one Jewish and one Palestinian, each offering a different history and narrative of the city. Sarah tells success stories of tourists from the US visiting a Palestinian refugee camp and listening to joint Arab and Jewish bands play music, and of a Muslim family from the UK sharing Sabbath dinner with a Jewish family and realizing that 100 years ago, their people came from the same town in Northern Africa. MEJDI is expanding its service to Iran, Turkey, Ireland and other regions suffering from cultural conflict. If more of the world’s 1 billion tourists were to engage with real people living real lives, argues Sarah, it would be a powerful force for shattering sterotypes and promoting understanding, friendship and peace.

Here are their stories", "duration": 881.0, "slug": "anders_fjellberg_two_nameless_bodies_washed_up_on_the_beach_here_are_their_stories", "viewed_count": 1296871}], "slug": "aziz_abu_sarah_for_more_tolerance_we_need_more_tourism", "speakers": [{"id": "1823", "slug": "aziz_abu_sarah", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Aziz", "lastname": "Abu Sarah", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Entrepreneur + educator", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/ff02218ac6acc05a6f2764de0225deea00459777_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Aziz Abu Sarah helps people break down cultural and historical barriers through tourism.", "whylisten": "

When Aziz Abu Sarah was a boy, his older brother was arrested on charges of throwing stones. He was taken to prison and beaten — and died of his injuries. Sarah grew up angry, bitter and wanting revenge. But when later in life he met, for the first time, Jews who were not soldiers, Sarah had an epiphany: Not only did they share his love of small things, namely country music, but coming face to face with the “enemy” compelled him to find ways to overcome hatred, anger and fear.

Sarah founded MEJDI Tours to send tourists to Jerusalem with two guides, one Jewish and one Palestinian, each offering a different history and narrative of the city. Sarah tells success stories of tourists from the US visiting a Palestinian refugee camp and listening to joint Arab and Jewish bands play music, and of a Muslim family from the UK sharing Sabbath dinner with a Jewish family and realizing that 100 years ago, their people came from the same town in Northern Africa. MEJDI is expanding its service to Iran, Turkey, Ireland and other regions suffering from cultural conflict. If more of the world’s 1 billion tourists were to engage with real people living real lives, argues Sarah, it would be a powerful force for shattering sterotypes and promoting understanding, friendship and peace.

"}], "speaker_name": "Aziz Abu Sarah", "tags": ["Middle East", "TED Fellows", "activism", "culture", "peace", "travel", "violence", "war"], "title": "For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism?", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1449397}]}
author: Aziz_Abu Sarah;
title: For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism?

aws-transcripts.transcript: I'm a tourism entrepreneur and a peace builder. But this is not how I started when I was seven years old. I remember watching television and seeing people throwing rocks and thinking This must be a fun thing to do. So I got out to the street and threw rocks. Not realizing I was supposed to throw rocks at Israeli cars instead ended up stoning my neighbor's cars. They were not enthusiastic about my patriotism. This is my picture with my brother. This is me, the little one, and I know what you're thinking. You used to look cute. What the heck happened to you? But my brother is older than me was arrested when he was 18 taken to prison and charges of throwing stones. He was beaten up when he refused to confess that he threw stones and as a result, had internal injuries that caused his death. Soon after he was released from prison, I was angry. I was bitter on. All I wanted was revenge, But that changed. When I was 18. I decided that I needed Hebrew to get a job, and going to study Hebrew in that classroom was the first time I ever met Jews who were not soldiers. And we connected over really small things, like the fact that I love country music, which is really strange for Palestinians, but was then that I realized also that we have a wall off anger off hatred and of ignorance that separate us. I decided that it doesn't matter. What happens to me were really matters is how I deal with it. And therefore I decided to dedicate my life to bringing down the walls that separate people. I do so through many ways. Tourism is one of them, but also media education. And you might be wondering, Really, Can tourism change? Things cannot bring down walls. Yes, tourism is the best sustainable way to bring down those walls and to create sustainable way of connecting with each other and creating friendships. In 2009 I cofounded Measure Detours, a social enterprise that aims to connect people with two Georgia friends, by the way, and what we'll do the model with it. For example, in Jerusalem, we would have to tour guides one Israeli and one Palestinian, guiding the trips together, telling history and narrative and archaeology and conflict from totally different perspectives. I remember running a trip together with a friend named Kobe Jewish congregation from Chicago. The trip was in Jerusalem and we took them to a refugee camp, Palestinian refugee camp, and there we had this amazing food. By the way, this is my mother. She's cool, and that's the Palestinian food called Malubay. It means upside down. You could get with rice and chicken and you flip it upside down. It's the best meal ever, and we'll eat together. Then we had a joint band, Israeli and Palestinian musicians, and we did some belly dancing. If you don't know any, l teach you later. But when we left, both sides there were crying because they did not want to leave. Three years later, those relationships still exist. Imagine with me if the 1,000,000,000 people who travel internationally every year travel like this not being taken in the bus from one side to another, from one hotel to another, taking pictures from the windows of their buses, off people and cultures but actually connecting with people. You know, I remember having a Muslim group from the UK going toe a house, often orthodox Jewish family and having their first Friday night dinners at Sabbath, dinner eating together, huh? Mean which is a Jewish food is to just having the connection of realizing after a while that Ah, 100 years ago, their families came out of the same place in northern Africa. This is not a photo profile for your Facebook. This is not disaster tourism. This is the future. Off travel. And I invite you to join me to do that, to change your travel. We doing it all over the world now from Ireland to Iran to Turkey. And we see ourselves going everywhere to change the world. Thank you.
